author: Robert Harley
title: Grandson Janusz takes full control of LJ Hooker
text:
Janusz Hooker has cemented control of LJ Hooker, the real estate firm started in 1928 by his grandfather. by Robert Harley ï»¿
Janusz Hooker, the grandson of Sir Leslie Hooker, the founder of the real estate firm, LJ Hooker, has cemented his control of the high-profile real estate brand, buying out several well-known shareholders.
Former LJ Hooker chairman, Greg Paramor, former Leighton chief executive Wal King, property developer and yachting identity Syd Fischer, and the founder of RAMS, John Kinghorn have all sold out of the business.
The deal, foreshadowed in The Australian Financial Review , was confirmed on Friday by LJ Hooker chief executive, Grant Harrod.
"The company's ownership now rests with a tight group of investors who are each strategically valuable to the company," he wrote.
"The shareholders are proud of the performance of the company to date and excited about the opportunities ahead."
Mr Harrod said Hooker would now have a smaller board of directors which would be "empowered to make quick decisions to leverage today's market and the wealth of new opportunities as they arise."
The previous consortium bought the business from Suncorp in 2009 for $67 million, with high expectations for a turnaround, repricing and possible float.
 It took longer than expected. Nine months ago they put the business up for sale and since then have worked through several options for full and partial sales with Australian and international investors.
No financial details of the agreement have been provided, but the outgoing investors will make money on the deal.
LJ Hooker, launched by the legendary Sir Leslie Hooker in 1928, remained one of the nation's best-known brands.
The group had more than 700 franchise offices and 8000 people across Australia and in New Zealand, the Pacific and Asia, along with international partnerships. Beyond the ubiquitous real estate shops, the group had a commercial real estate franchise network and, in LJ Hooker Home Loans, a significant mortgage broking operation.
For almost 20 years, after the collapse of Hooker Corporation in the early 1990s, LJ Hooker languished under the control of Suncorp.
The new owners had to inject more capital into the business and upgrade the management, first under Mr Hooker and then under George Chmiel, now director of the listed iProperty Group, and since 2013 under former Salmat chief executive Grant Harrod.
Mr Harrod wrote that that business would "continue to work together to build Australasia's number one real estate group."
